title: Global Bond Selloff; Google Avoids Chrome Sale in Antitrust Case
description: US equity futures bounce back and the selloff in global bonds slightly eases after the US 30-year yield nears 5%. Google avoids a sale of its Chrome browser after a judge ruled in its antitrust case. Max Kettner of HSBC says he doesn't necessarily see contagion in bonds. Aaron Kennon of Clear Harbor Asset Management sees five to six Fed rate cuts between now and December 2026. Petrobras CEO Magda Chambriard exclusively tells Bloomberg's Annmarie Hordern that Asia will help counter the pressure of the US trade war. “Bloomberg Brief” delivers the market news, data and analysis you need to set your agenda. (Source: Bloomberg)

summary: Google has been denied the sale of its Chrome Business in a recent Antitrust Case, citing a 5.5% increase in its sales. This decision is seen as a significant setback for the global Bond Market. Other notable developments include YIELDS, JAPAN's 30-year YIELD UP ANOTHER SEVEN BASIS POINTS, and MACY's. Despite these setbacks, the Nasdaq FUTures have only risen by five to five%. shortSummary: Google Avoids Chrome sale in Antitrust case, amid severe bond market issues and volatile stock markets, with significant gains expected in tech stocks.
argos_summary: Global bond markets saw a selloff with U.S. 30‑year yields nearing 5%, while a U.S. judge ruled that Google need not sell its Chrome browser in an antitrust case, lifting pressure on the company and boosting its shares. Equity futures rebounded, and analysts noted that bond contagion is unlikely, with HSBC’s Max Kettner citing idiosyncratic factors. Clear Harbor’s Aaron Kettner projected five to six Fed rate cuts between now and December 2026. Petrobras CEO Magda Chambriard highlighted Asia’s role in offsetting U.S. trade war impacts. Overall, markets remain volatile amid policy and corporate developments.
